file_content.text: Thank you for helping me, Jedi.
No, wait! Before you strike the killing blow, listen to me!
I hear Lord Vivicar's voice. I've failed him, just as I failed my old friend Parkanas, when he died.
Why does everyone mention Parkanas?
I've heard that name before.
Who is this Parkanas?
Parkanas?
He's... dead, a ghost, a memory. I keep thinking about our first mission, our ill-fated mission to Malachor Three.
I don't see how this is related.
Don't change the subject.
I keep thinking about our first mission, our ill-fated mission to Malachor Three.
Who is this Lord Vivicar and why is he forcing you to remember this old friend?
Lord Vivicar?
Why would Lord Vivicar force you to remember an old friend of yours?
Vivicar's making you remember?
I don't know. But I keep thinking about our first mission, our ill-fated mission to Malachor Three.
We were all weak. We all came under the thrall of the dark side. We did things we regretted. But Parkanas was our strength.
As we tried to escape, I fell behind, and he ran back to save me. He became trapped--we had to leave him. It was my weakness that killed him.
It's hard to lose a friend like that, but you have to move on.
You can't blame yourself.
I am trying to, that is the purpose of this project.
Parkanas knew the risk he was taking.
It's his own fault.
Yet I can't shake the feeling that he--his spirit--hates me for it. It is why I have thrown myself into this project.
Parkanas is one with the Force now.
A Jedi does not fear death.
Yes, I know the teaching, but still--it is why I have thrown myself into this project.
Think about it: The Jedi Order spends so much time protecting the helpless and caring for the sick, when we could be fighting the Empire.
You must kill me--I was weak on Malachor Three, and I'm weak now. But you must take my findings before the Council! Promise me that!
We'll discuss that in a second.
Not right now. [Shield.]
Let's see how you feel once Lord Vivicar no longer has a hold on you.
You're not yourself. [Shield.]
Ah. What--what was that? You... he's gone... somehow you've driven Lord Vivicar away. I no longer hear his voice.
I almost--I almost wish you hadn't done that.
What does Jedi mean? Herald saved Jedi's life!
Of all the ungrateful, impudent! This Jedi saved your life!
Master Eriz, this Jedi saved your life--how can you say that?
Lord Vivicar twisted my mind, and I'm glad to be free of him; still, my discovery remains.
From these Sand People, I have learned the key to building the unstoppable army.
I feel I must bring these findings to the Republic, yet I can't shake this feeling that some truths are best left buried in the sand.
Using this information would mean the sacrifice of every good the Republic stands for.
Bury it.
You're right. These records... are no more.
This knowledge is too dangerous for the Republic, but in the right hands, it could be very helpful.
Let the Jedi Council decide.
To defeat the Empire, the Republic will need every advantage.
This knowledge must be shared.
Yes. Knowledge like this mustn't be hidden. I will return to Anchorhead and make my report.
Thank you for your guidance, and for saving me from Vivicar's grasp.
Well, Jedi, I can't say I would've done the same thing, but I'm glad Master Eriz is alive, and his old self.
Well, Jedi, I'm glad Master Eriz is alive and his old self.
I'd best get back to Anchorhead myself. Sand Rot's acting up, and frankly, I sort of miss Darth Nurse's hollering.
It's been a pleasure.
Just get out of here, then.
So what are you waiting for?
Take care.
I've gotten by okay this far.
Good luck with whatever it is you're doing, Jedi. Hope you find this Lord Vivicar.
The Council will never hear your poisonous ideas.
No, I won't. [Kill him.]
Aargh!
Good riddance to him. I hate to say it, but he had me fooled. Better that you killed him than spread his sick ideas.
I wish it hadn't needed to end this way, but I couldn't let his ideas spread.
He gave me little choice.
Yeah, I guess so. He was a different guy than the one who was my friend, though.
The other option would have weakened me, and like he says, we must be strong to survive.
I was only saving myself.
Right... I'll take you at your word.
The fool was getting on my nerves.
He aggravated me.
Yeah, well, I guess that's a reason too.
Well... all that exertion's... the rot's acting up. Best get back to the clinic and take my berating from Darth Nurse.
It was good working with you, Jedi.
You'll never defeat me.
Rowan, Jedi. You are about to witness it... after weeks of work, finally, an end to the darkness.
These people, these marvelous, marvelous specimens, have been tested--no, purified--in the crucible of Tatooine's harsh environs.
They alone are the hope of the galaxy. Their strength, their society is the blueprint of our salvation!
Master Eriz, you are very ill.
You're not well.
No, not ill, not ill at all.
What do you mean "blueprint"?
Explain yourself.
These are savages, Master Eriz, and they are murdering innocent people!
You're wrong.
No, not savages. Not savages at all.
They are simple, but long after the Empire and the Republic are gone, these people will remain.
Their culture is built around strength. They cut the weak away like a societal cancer. Don't you see? It's the only way!
The Jedi Order has a responsibility to weak and strong alike.
The Jedi protect the weak.
The only way to do what?
The only way?
The darkness is strong, so we must be stronger. These are the ultimate warriors!
The plaguemaster has his fangs in you, deep.
You're being controlled.
Lord Vivicar has his fangs in you, deep.
You're being controlled.
How can I make you understand? They are the ultimate warriors, purified by hardship.
We must follow their example, and cut away everything that would make us weak in the face of our adversaries--the frail, the diseased!
You're not thinking straight. Look, I'm sick, Eriz--you gonna cast me out too?
I have no choice. We must fortify the Republic with its strongest members, and send this army of light out against the darkness.
You are not yourself. These are not your thoughts.
Fight the plague.
An army of light that neglects the weak is no longer light.
You must protect the weak.
I'd have a better chance of winning an argument with a rock.
You're hopeless. [Attack.]
You fools. To oppose me is to reveal your own weakness. You will be cast out!
I'm sorry, I have nothing to say to you.
